It's a Sunday evening and about 200 students of Beulah Heights Bible College and their families have gathered for the graduation ceremony.
Benson Karanja, the school president, steps up to the podium.
Please repeat this with me: By God's grace, I am here.
It's something Karanja says to himself every day as he thinks of the journey that brought him here.
I was born in Kenya in the small town of Nakuru almost 52 years ago.
Karanja was born during Kenya's colonial period, when whites owned the land.
His father was a peasant farmer working for a white family.

Most of the time, when the master had gone to the city, I had an opportunity for my father to sneak me in the house and expose me to the Western civilization, like see the radio for the first time, see the toilet with flushing water, which was not known in a village.
So it was amazing to be there.
Kenya's independence in the early 1960s dramatically changed Karanja's life.
Black Africans were allowed to own land and Karanja thrived.
Working hard as a farmer and striking clever deals, he became a wealthy businessman.
Then, in 1987, he was invited to an economic summit of international black leaders in Atlanta.
That's when he decided he should go to college.
For what?
I didn't know for what I was supposed to go, but I felt the urge that maybe I just need to go to a Bible college.
Karanja picked up a brochure about Beulah Heights Bible College.
It's one of the oldest Bible colleges in the south, with a substantial African-American and international student body.
A few months later, with acceptance letter in hand, Karanja moved to Atlanta, along with his wife and three children.
And he began a second rags-to-riches story.
The only job I could work was to work on campus, and the only job they could give me was to be a janitor.
Karanja began scrubbing toilets at this small school in Atlanta.
He says it taught him humility that he applies to his life today.
It trained me to be more sensitive and to be more human, and to be a leader, understanding that it is an opportunity that I have been given, in times such as this, to lead.
But I'm not bitter.
After graduating with a degree in biblical studies, Karanja worked his way up the ranks at Beulah Heights.
